fact: Carbon dioxide accounts for 65% of global greenhouse gas emissions.
Methane accounts for 16% of global greenhouse gas emissions.
25% of global emissions are generated by the energy sector.
95% of the world's transportation energy comes from petroleum-based fuels.
Burning coal, natural gas, and oil for electricity and heat is the largest source of global emissions.
Since 1970, CO₂ emissions have increased by around 90%.
30% of global emissisions are generated by China, the highest per country.
Greenhouse gas emissions from the transport sector have more than doubled since 1970.
The shipping and aviation sectors account for 5 percent of global emissions.
The richest 1% of the global population account for more emissions than the poorest 50%.
The global average temperature in 2019 was 1.1 degrees Celsius above the pre-industrial period.
To prevent warming beyond 1.5°C, global emissions must reduce by 7.6% every year until 2030.
In 2020, cars made up 76% of the vehicle miles travelled in the UK.
In England, around 60% of 1-2 mile trips are made by car.
An average petrol car in the UK produces the equivalent of 180g of CO₂ every kilometre.
